author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Armani Takes Inspiration From … Armani
description: As a new generation seeks out vintage Armani on eBay, the label is leaning into its own archive. The Armani renaissance is officially on.
content: On Sunday evening, on the way to the Emporio Armani fashion show here, I did what I always do with … oh, six free minutes of my day: I checked eBay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: At Least 80 Dead and 18,000 Flee Amid a New Surge of Violence in Colombia
description: Clashes between armed groups in Colombia have led to some of the worst violence in the country in years.
content: At least 80 people are dead and more than 18,000 have been forced to flee their homes in Colombia, officials say, amid fierce clashes between two rival armed groups on the border with Venezuela.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: It’s Going to Be a Big News Day. Here’s What to Watch For.
description: From Donald J. Trump’s swearing-in to pardons, executive orders and more, the first day of the new administration promises to be busy and eventful.
content: President Biden used his clemency powers one last time before leaving office, issuing pre-emptive pardons. Donald J. Trump, the 45th president of the United States, will be sworn in as the 47th on a day that, because of wintry weather, will lack some of the usual pageantry of an inauguration even while marking a transfer of power free of the attempts to subvert a democratic election that hung over the last one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Bob Dylan’s Draft of Lyrics, Once Tossed in Trash, Sells for $500,000
description: Two pages of lyrics, written in the kitchen of a pioneering rock ‘n’ roll journalist, offer glimpses into the Nobel Prize-winning musician’s writing process.
content: Two sheets of yellowed stationery are crumpled but intact, with typewritten lyrics and scribbled changes that offer a rare glimpse into the creative process of their famed author as he penned one of the best-known songs of the 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Schiff
title: A King? A Pawn? A Rogue? The Founders Could Barely Imagine a President.
description: The young nation had seen many things, but a single executive? Surely not.
content: “How do you like our new Constitution?” Thomas Jefferson wrote to John Adams in mid-November 1787. Jefferson mostly wanted to vent. The two-month-old document left him reeling, especially in its provisions for a new chief executive. The American president, grumbled Jefferson, “seems a bad edition of a Polish king.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Fighting Has Halted in Gaza, but the War Is Not Over
description: Sunday’s delayed start to the truce was a minor problem compared with the difficult choices and American leverage needed to get both parties to the second phase, which could end the war.
content: At the end of a war in Gaza in 2021, Yahya Sinwar, the leader of Hamas, was photographed sitting in an armchair in his ruined home, a symbol of continuing resistance to Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,312
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Jan. 21, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold
title: Nonprofit Groups Sue Trump Administration Moments After Oath
description: Their lawsuits said the so-called Department of Government Efficiency, President Trump’s cost-cutting operation, violated a law requiring federal advisory committees to include a balance of views.
content: Nonprofit groups filed three lawsuits against President Trump’s administration minutes after he took office on Monday, arguing that his so-called Department of Government Efficiency was violating laws that require federal advisory committees to be open to the public and to include a diversity of viewpoints.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Emmett Lindner
title: Monday Briefing
description: The start of a truce in Gaza.
content: Hours after three Israeli women were released from captivity in the Gaza Strip yesterday, about 90 Palestinian prisoners were freed by Israel as its long-awaited cease-fire agreement with Hamas took effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Debate Over Trump’s Favorite Word Needs a Reset
description: Are tariffs good or bad policy? The answer is less simple than you might think.
content: The debate over tariffs has run into a dead end of thoughtless gainsaying. “Higher tariffs are good,” one side says. “No, they’re bad,” says the other. The superficiality of the arguments is a shame because the subject is deep and fascinating. Tariffs are certain to be even more important in the second Trump administration than they were in the first. We need to understand both their pros and their cons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Four More Years! Four More Years! Wait. Four More Years?
description: Meet the new boss. Same as the old boss.
content: Gail Collins: Well, Bret, here we are. Neither of us is crazy about staggering into another four-year Trump term, but I’ll bet you can come up with a more optimistic spin than I can. Go to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: ‘Prime Target,’ Plus 7 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: The new Apple TV+ series stars Leo Woodall as a math genius, and President-elect Donald J. Trump is inaugurated for his second term.
content: On Monday, President-elect Donald J. Trump will be inaugurated for his second term. And one question that rushes through the minds of Americans (or at least culture journalists at The New York Times) is: Who will perform? And now we know: During the swearing-in ceremony, Carrie Underwood will sing “America the Beautiful,” and the tenor Christopher Macchio will perform the national anthem. The Village People, Billy Ray Cyrus and Gavin DeGraw will perform at the various inauguration balls and rallies. Coverage starting at 10 a.m. on several networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Liz Alderman
title: Paris Olympics Medals Are Tarnishing, Putting LVMH in the Spotlight
description: The medals were designed by a jewelry maker owned by the French luxury conglomerate, which has declined to comment on their deterioration.
content: Rarely in Olympic history had a single company been as ubiquitous as LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the luxury goods empire owned by France’s richest family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: Trump Takes Office as a Newly Minted Crypto Billionaire
description: The Trump family’s new crypto tokens, which went on sale over the weekend, have soared in value — along with crypto markets in general.
content: The Trump family’s new crypto tokens are worth well over $10 billion on paper, after a frenzied rally pushed up the value of the digital assets in the days before the inauguration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: This Quick Noodle Soup Is Vivid in Every Sense of the Word
description: This creamy butternut squash and coconut noodle soup from Christian Reynoso boasts an incredible color and a perfectly calibrated sour-spicy tang.
content: Wishing you all a good Monday. Today is both Inauguration Day and the federal holiday for Martin Luther King’s Birthday. M.L.K. Day is also a national day of service, the only federal holiday that encourages people to volunteer to help improve their communities. For me, this usually includes baking cookies to drop off at a local food pantry (you can’t go wrong with chocolate chip). If you have the day off, cooking something delicious and sharing it with others might be just the way to spend a couple of hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: ‘American Carnage 2: Ultimate Carnage’: Best and Worst Moments From Trump’s Inaugural Address
description: Fourteen Opinion writers assess the substance and style of Trump’s speech.
content: President Trump delivered a searing Inaugural Address on Monday, taking aim at the Biden administration, which he accused of a “horrible betrayal,” and promising to make the United States the “envy of every nation,” “proud, prosperous and free.” Here’s what Times Opinion columnists and contributors thought of his speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Rescuing Pongo, Pearl, Bandit, Tiger and Zipper
description: Throughout the burn zone, Angelenos struggled to save their pets. Among the most difficult to save are those that live in water.
content: David Pierce shouted to his wife, Jane Pierce, to pack, as embers rained down on their block in Altadena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Hamas Official Says Group Is Ready for ‘Dialogue With America’
description: In a rare move hours after the cease-fire took effect, one senior Hamas official said the group wants to engage the new Trump administration.
content: Hours after the cease-fire between Israel and Hamas took effect, a senior Hamas official said that the militant group was ready to start a dialogue with the United States, making a rare overture to a country that Hamas has long excoriated for supporting Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Cites His Own Victories as Sign He Will Lift a Country in ‘Decline’
description: In his second inaugural address, the president reprised dark themes from his first and laid out an expansive policy agenda.
content: If his first inaugural address was a relentlessly dark vision of “American carnage,” President Trump made his second one a paean to the power of one person’s ability to rescue a nation — specifically his.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones and Amy Graff
title: Southern California Is Threatened by More Damaging and Dangerous Winds
description: With more critical fire weather this week in Los Angeles, the National Weather Service once again issued one of its strongest warnings possible.
content: Southern California was bracing Monday for another round of powerful, sweeping winds in and around Los Angeles, where the landscape remains dangerously starved of rain and firefighters are still working to fully contain wildfires that have left at least 27 people dead and destroyed thousands of homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: You’ve Been Invited to a Secret House Party in London
description: Details are in Caleb Femi’s new poetry collection, “The Wickedest.”
content: What was poetry? That’s the question John Koethe asked in “Beyond Belief,” his 2022 collection of verse. He was speaking about how poems come and go but none seem to make an impression. Lucy Sante framed this somewhat differently when she asked, “Was ‘Howl’ the last poem to hit the world with the impact of news and grip it with the tenacity of a pop song?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Can I Get Out of My Leggings Rut?
description: Our fashion critic proposes alternative pant styles to a reader searching for a comfortable yet fashionable replacement to leggings in public.
content: Karl Lagerfeld, the longtime Chanel designer and coiner of many biting aphorisms, once dismissed sweatpants as “a sign of defeat.” It is possible that, were he alive today, he would say the same thing about leggings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Trump Is the Oldest President to Take the Oath, Again
description: Before Joseph R. Biden Jr. was sworn in 2021, Donald J. Trump held the record for the country’s oldest commander in chief. He reclaimed the record on Monday.
content: When Donald J. Trump became the 45th president of the United States in 2017, he was the oldest, at 70 years old, to be sworn into office. But then, Joseph R. Biden Jr. upended that record when he took the oath at 78, in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: Food and Other Vital Aid Surge Into Gaza After 15 Months of Scarcity
description: Hunger has gripped the enclave, besieged by Israel, and the surge is a step toward alleviating it. But with Hamas asserting its grip on Gaza, questions remain about how aid is distributed.
content: The amount of humanitarian aid entering Gaza surged dramatically on Sunday, with more than 630 trucks entering the impoverished and hungry enclave on the first day of the cease-fire, according to United Nations officials — the highest figure since the start of the war more than 15 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For Trump, a Vindication for the Man and His Movement
description: Donald John Trump took the oath of office again during a ceremony in the Capitol, promising a new “golden age of America” four years after he was evicted by voters.
content: Donald John Trump completed an extraordinary return to power on Monday as he was sworn in as the 47th president of the United States and opened an immediate blitz of actions to begin drastically changing the course of the country and usher in a new “golden age of America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meaghan Tobin and Claire Fu
title: TikTok Got a Reprieve, but Americans and Chinese Are Still on RedNote
description: The Chinese social media app, popular in the United States a week after being flooded by TikTok users, has added language translation features.
content: TikTok got an apparent reprieve from being forced to shut down, but Americans on Monday were still using and downloading Xiaohongshu, the Chinese social media app that surged in popularity last week in anticipation of TikTok’s closure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2,000 Rentals in Los Angeles
description: A studio apartment in Koreatown, one-bedroom units in Long Beach and East Hollywood, and links to resources for those displaced by the fires.
content: To provide a resource for those displaced by the Los Angeles fires, this edition of “What You Get” focuses on rentals rather than for-sale properties. The asking rents in today’s article roughly match the median asking rents for studios and one-bedrooms in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erika Solomon
title: Mother of Missing U.S. Journalist Asks Syria’s New Leaders for Help
description: Debra Tice, whose son Austin was abducted near Damascus in 2012, said the rebel group that toppled the Assad regime promised support in helping to find him.
content: The mother of Austin Tice, an American journalist abducted in Syria, said on Monday that she had met with Syria’s new leader in Damascus and expressed hope that “a page will be turned” in the more than decade-long search for her son.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Here’s the latest.
description: Donald J. Trump has promised a burst of action once he has been sworn into office again, including a wide range of executive orders intended to steer federal policy on immigration, the federal work force, energy and the environment, the economy and trade, gender issues and diversity, equity and inclusion programs.
content: Donald J. Trump has promised a burst of action once he has been sworn into office again, including a wide range of executive orders intended to steer federal policy on immigration, the federal work force, energy and the environment, the economy and trade, gender issues and diversity, equity and inclusion programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Pardoned Biden Family Members Were Targets of Republicans
description: The relatives who were granted clemency in the final minutes of Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidency had not been charged with wrongdoing, but some had drawn scrutiny.
content: Former President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s last-minute pre-emptive pardons to five family members came after years of scrutiny from Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Isabel Kershner and Eric Nagourney
title: Gazans Return to Vast Destruction in Old Neighborhoods
description: Palestinians returning to parts of the enclave have been picking their way through vast piles of rubble and trying to salvage what they can.
content: Gazans took in the scale of devastation to their old neighborhoods and Israelis awaited news about three newly released hostages as a day-old cease-fire between Hamas and Israel continued to hold on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: At Inauguration, Melania and Barron Trump Greet a Limelight They Once Avoided
description: The returning first lady and Barron Trump, the son she had once shielded from the public eye, used Monday’s inauguration to reintroduce themselves.
content: During her husband’s first presidential inauguration, in January 2017, Melania Trump was a newcomer to Washington, a first lady who draped herself in baby-blue cashmere to evoke memories of Jacqueline Kennedy and whose tight smile, at moments, seemed to dissolve into a scowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Michael D. Shear and Noah Weiland
title: Trump’s Executive Orders: Reversing Biden’s Policies and Attacking the ‘Deep State’
description: The president moved swiftly in his first hours in office, signing a slew of executive orders in front of a roaring crowd and then in the Oval Office.
content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Armed Services Panel Rushes Through Hegseth Nomination Along Party Lines
description: Republicans moved in private over the objections of Democrats. A last-minute bid to delay the vote failed.
content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: In renaming Denali for McKinley, Trump invokes a presidential idol
description: The move is likely to face some pushback in Alaska, where the Alaska Native name has long been favored for the continent’s tallest mountain.
content: President Trump announced on Monday that he would sign an executive order renaming the tallest mountain in North America as Mount McKinley, undoing a 2015 decision that had restored the peak’s Alaska Native name, Denali.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: On a Cold, Dark Inauguration Day, a Message From the Birds
description: Seeing those cardinals watching over each other, I wondered: What can I, too, do to be watchful? To take care?
content: Just before dark on New Year’s Eve, I filled all the bird feeders, and I didn’t skimp on the good stuff: black nyjer thistle for the finches, two kinds of suet for the woodpeckers, whole peanuts for the crows and the blue jays, a high-protein woodland mix dense with shelled peanuts and sunflower hearts for everybody. The birds would wake to a New Year’s feast. I thought of it as the avian equivalent of the black-eyed peas and greens that the humans in the house would be eating for good luck later in the day. In 2025 we will be needing all the luck we can get.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Vance’s Swift Rise to Vice President Leaves Time to Determine Legacy
description: At age 40, a relative newcomer who made his name on the campaign trail for his fierce attacks on Democrats is first in the line of succession for president.
content: James David Vance took an astonishing step in his meteoric political rise on Monday when he was sworn in as the youngest vice president of the United States in more than 70 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Jillian Weinberger
title: Trump Won’t Change the Fact That America Needs Immigrants
description: Binyamin Appelbaum argues that immigration is America’s rocket fuel.
content: Donald Trump has promised to severely curtail legal and illegal immigration as he takes office for the second time. In this episode of “The Opinions,” the writer Binyamin Appelbaum argues that while the United States needs to improve its immigration enforcement, the country also desperately needs immigrants for cultural and economic vibrancy. Immigrants, Appelbaum explains, are the country’s “rocket fuel,” and he argues for specific legal changes to ensure the United States’ immigration policy matches its national interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: TikTok, RedNote and the Crushed Promise of the Chinese Internet
description: China’s internet companies and their hard-working, resourceful professionals make world-class products, in spite of censorship and malign neglect by Beijing.
content: The Chinese social media app RedNote is full of cute, heartwarming moments after about 500,000 American users fled to it last week to protest the looming U.S. government ban on TikTok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: What to Know About the Singers Who Will Perform at the Inauguration
description: The country singers Carrie Underwood and Lee Greenwood and the tenor Christopher Macchio are all scheduled to sing at the swearing-in ceremony.
content: Current pop hitmakers won’t be performing at the inauguration ceremony. Instead, the program will feature two country singers — Carrie Underwood and Lee Greenwood — and an opera singer, Christopher Macchio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Do LED Face Masks Work?
description: These light-emitting devices are all over the internet. We asked experts if they can reduce wrinkles, clear acne and more.
content: You’ve probably noticed this scene on social media: People (usually women) lounging on couches or in beds while wearing serial-killer-style face masks with colorful lights emanating from beneath them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: Portrait of General Milley Is Removed From Pentagon
description: The decision was an early salvo by the new administration against a military that President Trump has assailed for a variety of perceived offenses.
content: The Pentagon on Monday removed a portrait of Gen. Mark A. Milley, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, from a corridor of the building filled with paintings of all of his predecessors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 590
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Jan. 21, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Hari Kumar
title: Life in Prison for Hospital Rape and Murder That Shocked India
description: The police had sought the death penalty in a horrific but familiar crime. Its handling by the local authorities had outraged the nation.
content: An Indian court on Monday sentenced to life in prison the man convicted of raping and murdering a trainee doctor in Kolkata, sparing him the death penalty in a case that was a chilling example of how the country remains unsafe for women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green and Remy Tumin
title: Cecile Richards, Former Planned Parenthood President, Dies at 67
description: She oversaw the United States’ largest provider of reproductive health care and sex education from 2006 to 2018.
content: Cecile Richards, the dynamic former president of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America and one of the country’s most well-known defenders of abortion rights, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman, William K. Rashbaum and Maggie Haberman
title: In Shake-Up, Trump Administration Jolts F.B.I. by Installing Acting Leader
description: Christopher A. Wray, the former director, stepped down Sunday. Brian Driscoll, who recently took charge of the F.B.I.’s Newark field office, will be acting director.
content: The Trump administration said on Monday that it had named two veteran agents to run the F.B.I. as the bureau braces for potentially tumultuous changes under a president who has repeatedly denounced the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Trump’s Family Stands by His Side at His Inauguration
description: President Trump’s relatives return to Washington with more political and cultural support — and a far better understanding of how to wield their soft power.
content: The inauguration of Donald J. Trump is not just a restoration of power for the former president. It’s a return for his family, as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: This Day Calls for Martin Luther King’s Vision
description: The troubled times many of us feel we are in make his message especially relevant.
content: On Monday we’re celebrating Martin Luther King Jr. Day and inaugurating Donald Trump as the 47th president of the United States. That may seem like an odd pairing, especially to those of us who believe Mr. Trump has fueled a culture of skepticism, denial and indifference to matters of injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: The White House Website Got a Quick Trump Makeover
description: New administrations move quickly to replace the site, and Mr. Trump’s struck a starkly different tone from the message the Biden administration had offered.
content: President Trump’s administration quickly put its imprint on the official White House website on Monday, ushering out the Biden years with a new landing page that declared “America Is Back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Trump Changes Begin
description: We cover the start of Donald Trump’s second term.
content: The second Trump administration becomes a reality at noon Eastern today. In today’s newsletter, my colleagues and I look at seven areas where Donald Trump is likely to make immediate changes to government policy. For each area, we’ll also highlight one big unknown that will start to become clear in coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: Their Homes Are Intact, but the Fire Damage Inside Is Unbearable
description: Some evacuees from the Eaton fire have been allowed back into their homes, only to find that smoke and ash have made living there impossible for now.
content: As soon as an evacuation order was lifted in her neighborhood, Arlynn Page raced back to her charred street in Altadena, Calif., to see what was left of her hillside home. The two houses next door were rubble, but hers was unscathed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Biden commutes prison sentence of Leonard Peltier, an Indigenous rights activist convicted in F.B.I. killings.
description: Leonard Peltier spent nearly 50 years in federal prison.
content: President Biden commuted the prison sentence of Leonard Peltier, an imprisoned Native American rights activist, using his final minutes of presidential power on Monday to free a man who has spent nearly 50 years in federal prison after he was convicted of murder in connection with the killing of two F.B.I. agents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Do Chimps Who Urinate Together Stay Together?
description: Scientists suspect that contagious urination, a behavior they observed among a troop of apes in Japan, may play an important role in primate social life.
content: Ena Onishi, a doctoral student at Kyoto University, has spent over 600 hours watching chimpanzees urinating. She has a good reason for all that peeping, though. She is part of a team of researchers that recently discovered that the primates tend to tinkle when they see nearby chimps do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Goldsmith
title: Trump Doesn’t Have What It Takes to Be a Great President
description: Pushing power to the limit does not guarantee presidential success.
content: Donald Trump enters his second presidency, as he did his first, pledging to wield executive power in novel and aggressive ways. This is neither new nor necessarily bad. “Presidents who go down in the history books as ‘great’ are those who reach for power, who assert their authority to the limit,” the presidential scholar Richard Pious noted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Wagner Waits and Hopes Voters Don’t Close Out His Hall Candidacy
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 20, 2025.
content: “It’s going to be a very overwhelming moment for me, or it’s going to be a very painful moment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Some Jan. 6 Rioters Are Expected to Be in Washington for the Inauguration
description: At least eight rioters who have faced criminal charges have been granted permission to attend. Most were accused of relatively minor offenses.
content: Among the thousands of people who will descend on Washington on Monday for President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, a handful are expected to be criminal defendants charged with joining the mob that stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, on Mr. Trump’s behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Edgar Sandoval and Reyes Mata III
title: On a Quiet U.S.-Mexico Border, a Feeling of Disquieted Anticipation
description: Law enforcement officials and migrants on the U.S.-Mexico border were not sure what might come next, now that President Trump is back.
content: Sheriff Tom Schmerber, an elected Democrat in Maverick County, Texas, was watching on a television in his office near the U.S.-Mexico border on Monday as President Trump delivered his second inaugural address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Ends a Half-Century in Public Life on a Somber Note
description: “We’re not leaving the fight,” he told supporters and members of his staff as he prepared to leave Washington.
content: For four years as president, and for almost a half-century more in public life, Joseph R. Biden Jr. professed an optimistic, ironclad belief in the strength of America’s democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Scores of Senior Diplomats Are Leaving Posts as Trump Takes Office
description: The departures are common when a transition takes place, but it is now happening more quickly and on a larger scale than under previous administrations, a U.S. official said.
content: A transition team for President Trump has asked scores of senior career diplomats to resign from their positions on Monday, as soon as Mr. Trump takes office, and many of those asked to step down intend to do so, two U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Theodore Schleifer
title: Musk Is Likely to Get a West Wing Office for His Cost-Cutting Project
description: The world’s richest man had been expected to be situated in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, but a West Wing office would give him closer access to President Trump.
content: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, is likely to be given office space in the West Wing, putting him close to President Trump as Mr. Musk steers a project that aims to cut as much as $2 trillion in government spending, two people with knowledge of the planning said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim
title: At Prototype Festival, Opera With Lynchian Strangeness
description: This year’s Prototype, a showcase of experimental opera and theater, was stylistically broad but the focus was on the human voice in all its weirdness.
content: Even before news of his death broke on Thursday, the spirit of the director David Lynch hovered over the Prototype Festival. For 12 years, this annual showcase of experimental opera and music theater has hewed to a Lynchian aesthetic, with works that mine emotional extremes and blur the boundaries of reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Mowbray and Amrita Chandradas
title: Never Heard of Yogyakarta? It Might Be the Center of the Universe.
description: The Indonesian city is home to some of the greatest Hindu and Buddhist temples, a thriving food scene and an area known as the Cosmological Axis, a cradle of Javanese culture.
content: The long ride from the international airport to the city of Yogyakarta on the Indonesian island of Java at least has the virtue of easing a jet-lagged traveler through a liminal zone of rice-paddy plains and jungle hills. Then the buzzy metropolis closes round, and everything is all business and hot tropical urban disarray. Streets thrum with a zillion scooters in what was once nicknamed “kota sepeda,” bicycle city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Thielman
title: The ‘Hellboy’ Artist Makes a New Playground
description: Mike Mignola’s “Bowling With Corpses” is full of suspicious shadows and offbeat jokes.
content: I’m sure the artist Mike Mignola has, at some point, drawn a straight line, but it wasn’t recently. In “Bowling With Corpses & Other Strange Tales From Lands Unknown,” his work is at its most willfully cockeyed. Every tower and parapet stands at an improbable angle to all the others, every staircase appears on the cusp of collapse and the only things that look truly stable in this unfamiliar world — a new fantasy realm for Mignola, best known as the artist behind “Hellboy” — are the tree branches, the tentacles and the plentiful undead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Michael Rothfeld
title: Eric Adams Attends Inauguration of President Who Could Pardon Him
description: The New York City mayor canceled plans to honor Dr. Martin Luther King to attend the inauguration of Donald J. Trump, who has said he is considering pardoning Mr. Adams in his federal corruption case.
content: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City traveled to Washington on Monday for President Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, following weeks of speculation over whether the mayor would attend and the motivations behind his overtures toward Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Rotunda Ransacked by Pro-Trump Mob on Jan. 6 Will Be His Inauguration Backdrop
description: The large domed expanse, a breathtaking and solemn space in the Capitol, was the scene of mayhem wrought by Trump supporters four years ago. A very different crowd of his backers will be on hand Monday.
content: When Donald J. Trump takes the oath of office on Monday in a rare indoor inaugural ceremony under the Capitol dome, the grand Rotunda will be packed with dignitaries, lawmakers and supporters of the incoming president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Melania Trump Tips Her Hat
description: Inauguration fashion statements from the first lady — as well as the second.
content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar, Remy Tumin and Yan Zhuang
title: As Brutal Cold Settles Across U.S., Gulf Coast Braces for Rare Winter Storm
description: Snow and sleet started falling in Texas as officials begin to close schools and airports. Snow and ice could bring major travel disruptions and power outages from Texas to Florida.
content: Officials across a wide swath of the southern United States were urging residents to stay home on Tuesday as a significant winter storm swept through the region and was expected to bring heavy snow and frigid temperatures to areas unaccustomed to the weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Does a Strong Holiday Shopping Season Mean a Better Year Ahead?
description: Consumers spent more than expected over the holidays on clothes and electronics. But the retail economy is still a mixed bag.
content: The retail industry’s report card for the critical holiday shopping season is in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brenda Wineapple
title: The Tragedies That Came After Freedom in the American South
description: “Somewhere Toward Freedom” tells the story of Sherman’s March to the Sea from the perspective of the formerly enslaved.
content: Commanding an army of some 60,000 men, in late 1864, Maj. Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman marched the 300 miles from Atlanta to Savannah in 37 days. Sherman, who had taken Atlanta in September, intended to defeat the Confederacy by inflicting on its heartland the terrible consequences of a war the Southern secessionists had begun. A bit of audacious military strategy that’s assumed almost mythic proportions, Sherman’s March to the Sea has been depicted as barbaric, brilliant, Napoleonic — a “grand adagio movement,” as the diarist George Templeton Strong astutely called it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk Ignites Online Speculation Over the Meaning of a Hand Gesture
description: Speaking at a celebratory rally in Washington, Mr. Musk twice extended his arm out with his palm facing down, drawing comparisons to the Nazi salute.
content: Elon Musk ignited speculation and chatter online when he made a hand gesture twice during a speech celebrating President Trump on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saul Newman
title: Sorry, No Secret to Life Is Going to Make You Live to 110
description: Some of the claims behind the longest-lived people are simply improbable.
content: The allure of extreme longevity has beckoned for centuries. Research careers and marketing campaigns have been built on the idea that we can live longer, healthier lives by emulating long-lived people. It is a comforting thought, frequently used for research funding bids and to sell cookbooks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: The Deal Maker in Chief Is Back
description: The business world is expecting big changes — and potential disruptions — as Donald Trump returns to the White House.
content: Good morning on this Inauguration Day. Welcome to Round 2 of President Donald Trump. No matter your politics, it is likely to be a historic ride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Mexico Is Getting Ready for Trump. Here’s What’s Different This Time.
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum is detaining more migrants, seizing more fentanyl and positioning her country as a key ally against China. But the U.S. stance has shifted, too.
content: For the second time in less than decade, Mexico is preparing to negotiate with President-elect Donald J. Trump, who is threatening the neighboring country with sky-high tariffs, mass deportations and military strikes on cartels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde McGrady and Rick Rojas
title: The Search for Lessons in Trump’s Return on Martin Luther King Day
description: The dual celebrations of a second Trump inauguration and the civil rights leader’s birth raise profound questions about Black leadership and progress toward the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s dream.
content: On Monday, America will observe both the birth of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whose vision of pluralism, democracy and racial justice made him the most revered civil rights leader of the last century, and the return to office of President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump Promises Tariffs on Canada and Mexico, and Paves Way for Further Trade Action
description: The president said he planned to put tariffs on America’s neighbors on Feb. 1, as he signed an executive order mandating a sweeping review of U.S. trade policy.
content: President Trump said on Monday night that he planned to impose a 25 percent tariff on products from Canada and Mexico on Feb. 1 and might impose levies on most American imports, as he signed an executive order directing federal agencies to deliver a sweeping review of U.S. trade policies by this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Trump Orders a U.S. Exit From the World’s Main Climate Pact
description: The United States will be one of only four countries outside the Paris Agreement, which is designed to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions.
content: President Trump on Monday signed an executive order to withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement, the pact among almost all nations to fight climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Sapna Maheshwari, Eric Krupke, Diana Nguyen, Michael Simon Johnson, Mary Wilson, Brendan Klinkenberg, Marc Georges, Maria Byrne, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The TikTok Flip-Flop
description: What happened to the popular video app? And what can Donald Trump actually do about it?
content: Over the past few weeks, users of the video app TikTok braced themselves for a national ban to take effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. Teen Pleads Guilty to Murder of 3 Girls in Dance Class Stabbing Attack
description: Axel Rudakubana on Monday admitted committing the deadly attack last July. Officials later said he had been referred to a government counterterrorism program three times before his rampage.
content: An 18-year-old British man on Monday admitted to murdering three girls and attempting to kill 10 other people during a brutal knife attack at a dance class last July in Southport, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Madeleine Ngo
title: Ramaswamy Will Bow Out of Cost-Cutting Project and Run for Governor in Ohio
description: The billionaire decided he could not campaign while helping lead the so-called Department of Government Efficiency, but tensions with Elon Musk were also evident.
content: The advisory group called the Department of Government Efficiency is losing one of its leaders before it even begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Asthaa Chaturvedi
title: Officer Beaten by the Jan. 6 Mob Is On Duty Again, This Time to Protect Trump
description: Officer Daniel Hodges said he had come to grips with the idea that his professional duty now required him to protect a man whose supporters beat him, kicked him and tried to gouge his eyes out in 2021.
content: Four years ago, Officer Daniel Hodges was called upon to defend the Capitol against a pro-Trump mob and wound up being pinned by the throng in a doorway of the building, in one of the most searing images of the violence that erupted on Jan. 6, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: L.A. officials say they are better prepared for dangerous winds.
description: With powerful winds sweeping through Southern California again, top Los Angeles officials said they were prepared to handle yet another period of extreme fire danger in the city.
content: With powerful winds sweeping through Southern California again, top Los Angeles officials said they were prepared to handle yet another period of extreme fire danger in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu and Jamie Leventhal
title: Trump Repeats Inaccurate Claims in Inaugural Remarks
description: In his Inaugural Address, President Trump delivered a more tempered version of election talking points. But in remarks afterward, he reprised his grievances about the 2020 election.
content: President Trump began his second administration much as he left the first one, falsely questioning the outcome of the 2020 election and berating the criminal justice system in remarks throughout the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Border Patrol Agent Is Killed in Vermont Shooting
description: Officials said the agent was shot on Interstate 91, which was closed for several hours near the border with Canada.
content: A U.S. Border Patrol agent was shot and killed on Monday afternoon on Interstate 91 in northern Vermont, about 12 miles from the Canadian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From an America Battered by Brutal Winter Cold
description: An intense blast of Arctic air blanketed the Mid-Atlantic and the Northeast with frigid temperatures, and a rare winter storm along the Gulf Coast.
content: When will it end?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow
title: Scarred, but Still Standing
description: Eli Saslow, a Times writer at large, reflects on visiting relatives who were forced to evacuate, and the little kindnesses everywhere.
content: One of my favorite things about making reporting trips to Los Angeles is that I always get to visit my uncle and his family at their condo in Pacific Palisades. Last week was different. They are new evacuees, bouncing between a friend’s apartment and a relative’s house in the suburbs, traveling across the city with a shared suitcase and Pixel, their beloved pet cockatiel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Trump Agenda Heralds an Economic Experiment for the U.S.
description: Tariffs and tax cuts amid high interest rates and lingering inflation will pose a test for the U.S. economy.
content: President Trump is poised to embark on an economic experiment that has never been tested as he prepares to carry out an agenda of tax cuts and tariff increases while interest rates are high and prices remain elevated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: How a Monument to Women Finally Won a Place on the National Mall
description: The Women’s Suffrage National Monument, which will be the Mall’s first dedicated to women’s history, overcame congressional and other roadblocks.
content: The end of a presidency tends to bring a rush of last-minute monument making, and Joe Biden’s was no different. In his final week in office, he designated nearly 850,000 acres of federal land in California as two new national monuments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leon E. Panetta
title: It’s Trump’s Messy, Dangerous World Now
description: The key to peace is strength, and the key to strength is leadership.
content: We live in an increasingly dangerous and threatening world. There are more flashpoints in today’s global geopolitics than we have seen in decades, presenting a generational challenge to the incoming administration of Donald Trump and all of America’s elected leadership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden, Emma Bubola, Stephen Castle, Andrew Higgins and Jim Tankersley
title: Inauguration Draws Leaders From Europe’s Right
description: Many of the European politicians expected to be in Washington on Monday share President-elect Donald J. Trump’s anti-immigrant stance.
content: Mainstream conservative lawmakers and politicians from Europe are planning to attend President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inauguration. But the European contingent is also expected to include leaders of some parties that are on the right-wing fringes in their own countries or have only recently begun to gain greater acceptance at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: ‘Starry Night,’ All Night Long, as a Van Gogh Blockbuster Ends
description: The National Gallery in London stayed open all night for die-hard fans of the Dutch painter. “Midnight offers more room for reflection,” one attendee said.
content: The moment well after midnight when one day slides into the next is usually a lonely time, observed by security guards and nurses, insomniacs and students cramming for exams. But this weekend, at the National Gallery in London, thousands of people were there together. They had come to see Friday into Saturday with some of the last paintings Vincent van Gogh ever made.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Paulina Villegas
title: Trump Shuts Down Migrant Entry App, Signaling the Start of His Crackdown
description: The president moved quickly to cancel the CBP One app, which allowed migrants to schedule appointments to gain entry into the United States, turning away potentially tens of thousands of migrants.
content: The Trump administration on Monday abruptly closed down a government program created by the Biden administration to allow migrants to use an app to secure an appointment for admission into the United States through legal ports of entry, signaling the start of President Trump’s promised crackdown at the southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: Trump Swears Oath Without His Hand on Bible, but He Wasn’t Required To
description: The tradition of swearing the oath of office on a Bible stretches back to George Washington, but not all presidents have observed it.
content: As Donald J. Trump raised his right hand to take the oath of office as president on Monday, his left stayed at his side. Although his wife, Melania Trump, held two Bibles, Mr. Trump did not put his hand on either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meryl Cates
title: Maria Tallchief: Making Ballet American, Chapter 1
description: Widely considered America’s first prima ballerina, Tallchief is being celebrated by New York City Ballet, where she was a Balanchine muse, in her centennial year.
content: The ballerina Maria Tallchief was having dinner with her husband, the choreographer George Balanchine, at the Russian Tea Room in Manhattan when the impresario Sol Hurok approached their table. “Don’t you think it’s time to have your wife dance ‘Firebird’?” Hurok, who owned the Chagall sets and costumes for the ballet, asked Balanchine as he invited himself to a seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump Takes Office
description: Plus, exploring Indonesia’s spiritual hub.
content: Donald Trump completed his remarkable return to power yesterday as he was sworn in as the 47th U.S. president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Mira Rojanasakul
title: Airborne Lead and Chlorine Levels Soared as L.A. Wildfires Raged
description: The findings give new insight into the dangers of urban wildfires that burn plastics and other chemicals in homes and property.
content: At the height of the Los Angeles County wildfires, atmospheric concentrations of lead, a neurotoxin, reached 100 times average levels even miles from the flames, according to early detailed measurements obtained by The New York Times. Levels of chlorine, which is also toxic at low concentrations, reached 40 times the average.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: At Trump’s Rally, the Contradictions Are in the Music
description: The president-elect danced along with Village People as his rally closed with a live performance of “Y.M.C.A.,” after Kid Rock and Lee Greenwood played.
content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 20, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fixing America’s Immigration System
description: Readers respond to an editorial with their own suggestions. Also: The benefits of virtual therapy; in praise of solitude; our warming planet.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: MSNBC Mourns and Fox Makes Merry as Trump Season 2 Premieres
description: The inaugural’s pageantry was interpreted in sharply different ways across the media spectrum. Podcasters weighed in, too.
content: Nobody summed up the funereal mood of MSNBC’s inauguration coverage on Monday quite like Rachel Maddow, the star anchor and de facto TV therapist for liberals who cannot bring themselves to believe that Donald Trump is, once again, the president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Trump Is Sworn In as President
description: Also, Biden issued several final-hour pardons. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: At 12:01 p.m. Eastern today, Donald Trump was sworn in as president of the United States. His return to the White House for a second term caps a political comeback unlike any other in U.S. history. He was voted out of office, impeached, indicted and convicted of 34 felonies. Now, Trump is leading the country again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Scenes of Elation as Hostages Released, but the Path Ahead Is Uncertain
description: Doctors at Sheba Medical Center said the three women are in stable condition, but little is known about what the former captives went through in Gaza.
content: Soon after her release from more than 470 days of captivity in Gaza, Emily Damari entered Sheba Medical Center, near Tel Aviv, wrapped in a large Israeli flag and smiling, video footage showed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez, Orlando Mayorquín and Loren Elliott
title: In Car-Loving Los Angeles, the Charred Remains of Vehicles Cut Deep
description: For many residents, a set of wheels is an extension of their home, a key to their income or a source of priceless memories.
content: Dozens of vehicles sit abandoned, covered in ash, along a stretch of Palisades Drive near Sunset Boulevard in the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles. There’s a pair of black boots beside a gray Subaru Crosstrek. Down the street, a pink backpack with the name Sonya on it has been left in a Tesla Model X. Nearby, a box of family photos remains in a partly melted red Lexus UX.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Mikayla Whitmore and Shawn Paik
title: Twelve Dudes and a Hype Tunnel: Scenes from the ‘Super Bowl for Excel Nerds’
description: At the Microsoft Excel World Championship in Las Vegas, there was stardust in the air as 12 finance guys vied to be crowned the world’s best spreadsheeter.
content: Like soccer players taking the field in a giant stadium, the 12 finalists ran through a glowing “hype tunnel,” some wearing jerseys with sponsorship logos. As an announcer bellowed introductions and cameras captured their every move, they approached a neon-lit stage to raucous cheers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Marco Rubio Is Confirmed by Senate as Secretary of State
description: The Florida senator becomes the United States’ 72nd chief diplomat, and the first Latino to hold the job.
content: The Senate confirmed Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, on Monday as America’s 72nd secretary of state, putting a former political rival of President Trump at the helm of American diplomacy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pivot Point
description: Life in the moment before everything changes.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Trump to Release Records on the Assassinations of the Kennedys and Martin Luther King
description: The incoming president said the move was aimed at improving government transparency.
content: Donald J. Trump has said he will quickly release records relating to the assassinations of President John F. Kennedy, his brother Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as part of measures to restore confidence in government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Pardons 5 Members of His Family in Final Minutes in Office
description: Mr. Biden emphasized that he did not believe his family did anything wrong, but he feared political attacks by Donald J. Trump.
content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump Will Strip Protections from Career Civil Servants, Miller Says
description: The incoming deputy chief of staff told lawmakers that early action would include directives to give President-elect Donald J. Trump more control over federal workers, as well as on energy and immigration.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump is planning a string of executive orders during his first days in office, including one to strip job protections from career civil servants, his top policy adviser told Republican members of Congress on Sunday, according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Claire van Kampen, 71, Playwright and Arranger of Early Music World, Dies
description: After she married Mark Rylance, the two often collaborated; her specialty was arranging music for Tudor-era plays. Then she wrote a period piece of her own.
content: Claire van Kampen, who created authentic musical worlds for period works starring her husband, Mark Rylance, including Shakespearean plays and the TV series “Wolf Hall,” and who, late in her career, wrote a play herself, “Farinelli and the King,” which had a successful run on Broadway with Mr. Rylance as the lead, died on Saturday in Kassel, Germany. She was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Philharmonic Breezes Through Wagner’s Epic ‘Ring’
description: The conductor Nathalie Stutzmann led Lorin Maazel’s coolly efficient 1987 distillation, “The ‘Ring’ Without Words,” at David Geffen Hall.
content: The Metropolitan Opera’s next “Ring” cycle is years away. But for local Wagnerians champing at the bit, the New York Philharmonic offered a teaser this weekend in the form of Lorin Maazel’s 1987 distillation “The ‘Ring’ Without Words.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden in Final Hours Pardons Relatives and Others to Thwart Trump Reprisals
description: President Biden used his executive clemency power to protect people targeted by Donald J. Trump, including five members of his family as well as Liz Cheney, Anthony S. Fauci and Mark A. Milley.
content: Follow live updates on the start of the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons, Isabelle Taft and Eileen Sullivan
title: Trump plans to put an end to birthright citizenship. That could be hard.
description: Incoming White House officials said the new president would sign an executive order meant to deny automatic citizenship for some people born in the United States. The Constitution could stand in the way.
content: President Donald J. Trump plans to order the end of birthright citizenship — the guarantee, rooted in common law and enshrined in the Constitution for more than 150 years, that anyone born in the United States is automatically an American citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jonathan Swan, Patrick Kingsley, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Trump Takes Office, and the TikTok Roller Coaster
description: Plus, women’s history on the National Mall.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jose Antonio Vargas
title: I Was an Undocumented Immigrant. I Beg You to See the Nuance in Our Stories.
description: The situations of undocumented immigrants are varied, and call for a variety of solutions.
content: Almost 14 years ago, I risked the life I had built for myself in the United States by coming out publicly as an undocumented immigrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The Line in Trump’s Speech That Will Echo in Time
description: The niceties of Donald Trump’s first speech as president couldn’t mask the darkness within — or the way he views his mission now.
content: “American carnage” was gone. No phrase in Donald Trump’s second Inaugural Address distilled his distemper quite like those chilling words from his first.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Living Through the Fires, and Covering Them
description: New York Times reporters have been writing personal portraits about the fires in the California Today newsletter. Here is a collection of their dispatches on what the disaster means to them, and to Los Angeles.
content: There was a period of my life when I went to Will Rogers State Historic Park all the time. My husband and I would drive to Pacific Palisades and park near the polo field, where they held real polo matches. We would hike past creeks and live oaks, and smell the eucalyptus. Sometimes we would peek into the preserved ranch house where Will Rogers, “the cowboy philosopher,” once lived. That house is gone now, burned to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, Brad Plumer, Rebecca F. Elliott and Eric Lipton
title: Trump Signs Orders to Promote Fossil Fuels and End Climate Policies
description: The president said he’d declare an energy emergency, increase drilling and end support for electric cars. His pivot to oil and gas follows the hottest year in recorded history.
content: Hours after his inauguration on Monday, President Trump signed a barrage of executive orders to grant his administration new powers to promote fossil fuels and to withdraw support for renewable energy, signaling that the United States government would no longer fight climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger, Theodore Schleifer and Jason Andrew
title: Tech Titans and Donors Hit D.C. to Toast Trump’s Inauguration
description: Fans of Donald J. Trump spent millions for the opportunity to jump from ballrooms to rooftops for lavish events held across Washington this weekend.
content: Late Sunday night, just hours before Donald J. Trump would be sworn in as America’s 47th president, his fans showed up ready to party in the president-elect’s honor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Big Banks Quit Climate Change Groups Ahead of Trump’s Term
description: Several large U.S. financial institutions, including the Federal Reserve, have withdrawn from the networks after years of growing political and legal pressure.
content: As the second presidency of Donald J. Trump begins, America’s largest banks and asset managers have abandoned one of the most overt symbols of their commitment to reaching green goals: climate action networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Huang, Rebecca Lieberman, Kalina Borkiewicz, Sarah Cahalan, Nick Corasaniti, Bora Erden, Alicia Parlapiano, Amy Schoenfeld Walker, Ashley Wu and Karen Yourish
title: A Closer Look at Who Attended President Donald J. Trump’s Second Inauguration
description: Former presidents, members of Congress, and tech C.E.O.s were among those present to witness Mr. Trump take the oath of office.
content: Former presidents, members of Congress, and tech C.E.O.s were among those present to witness Mr. Trump take the oath of office.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald Trump’s Second Inaugural Speech, Annotated
description: In the first remarks of his second term, President Trump painted a grim portrait of the country while declaring that “the golden age of America begins right now.”
content: In the first remarks of his second term, President Trump painted a grim portrait of the country while declaring that “the golden age of America begins right now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Corum
title: Words Used in Donald Trump’s Second Inaugural Address
description: Frequently mentioned words in historic speeches from Donald J. Trump to George Washington.
content: Frequently mentioned words in historic speeches from Donald J. Trump to George Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nader Ibrahim and Aaron Boxerman
title: ‘There’s Nothing Left’: Gaza Lies in Ruin
description: As a pause in fighting came into effect, displaced Gazans took stock of how destroyed their cities were after 15 months of a devastating war.
content: As a pause in fighting came into effect, displaced Gazans took stock of how destroyed their cities were after 15 months of a devastating war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Video by Shawn Paik
title: Highlights From the Microsoft Excel World Championship
description: The event’s organizer hopes to turn competitive Excel into a popular e-sport where pros compete for million-dollar prizes and big-league glory. That’s still a ways off.
content: The event’s organizer hopes to turn competitive Excel into a popular e-sport where pros compete for million-dollar prizes and big-league glory. That’s still a ways off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, John Pappas, Christina Shaman, Christina Thornell, Nikolay Nikolov and Pierre Kattar
title: Trump’s Unlikely Return to Power
description: Donald J. Trump is returning to the White House in a far stronger position. He’s facing a depleted opposition and a more compliant Congress. Jonathan Swan, a politics reporter for The New York Times, breaks down how President Trump overcame significant challenges to consolidate his power over the Republican Party and voters in the four years since he lost the 2020 presidential election.
content: Donald J. Trump is returning to the White House in a far stronger position. He’s facing a depleted opposition and a more compliant Congress. Jonathan Swan, a politics reporter for The New York Times, breaks down how President Trump overcame significant challenges to consolidate his power over the Republican Party and voters in the four years since he lost the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Elon Musk’s Hand Gestures During Speech Draw Speculation
description: Elon Musk made two hand gestures during a speech at an event celebrating President Trump’s inauguration that drew comparisons online to the “Fascist salute.”
content: Elon Musk made two hand gestures during a speech at an event celebrating President Trump’s inauguration that drew comparisons online to the “Fascist salute.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: ‘Golden Age of America Begins,’ Trump Says at Inauguration
description: After being sworn in as the 47th president of the United States, Donald Trump laid out parts of his policy agenda, including taking back the Panama Canal and renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America.
content: After being sworn in as the 47th president of the United States, Donald Trump laid out parts of his policy agenda, including taking back the Panama Canal and renaming the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America.
source.name: The New York Times
